title: Fox News Anchors Stunned - Punked By Guest?

comments.author: MustangTri72

comments.text:
+alejoSOTOful Funny thing. I wouldn't use the word irony in this case and I 
agree with you that this is sarcasm. But somehow the definition I found for 
irony fits fine: the expression of one's meaning by using language that 
normally signifies the opposite, typically for humorous or emphatic effect.

And it also says it is synonymous to sarcasm. I think it is similar but I 
don't think those two words are interchangeable, and I find it very unusual 
to describe this as irony.

comments.author: Claire Fisher

comments.text:
I love how he said that video games won't fuel as much imagination as a 
blade of grass. Whether he is being serious (most likely not) or joking, it 
makes no sense. Just look at games like Deus Ex, Fallout, BioShock, Shadow 
of the Colossus, etc. those games have tons of ideas that fuels imagination 
and thought. Especially Deus Ex and BioShock since they focus so heavily on 
the idea of free choice, philosophy, and political situations like 
governmental decay and conspiracy. There is more imagination and complexity 
in Deus Ex than any movie or book ever made that I know of.﻿
comments.author: ByTor1212

comments.text:
+skunkhammer I don't understand what you mean by something real. What makes 
a game any less real than a blade of grass. Yes it is a made up world that 
does't actually exist, but the ideas that are there are fully real and even 
the simplest details in it can really spark a flame for someones 
imagination. If you haven't played a game like Deus Ex or BioShock with 
such depth and attention to detail, you cannot understand it's possible 
impact on the imagination.
comments.author: ByTor1212

comments.text:
+channelvision98 I'm talking about the inspiration that can come from a 
game like Deus Ex or BioShock, which if you haven't played, you simply just 
cannot understand. While the game itself has confines, it can give 
some ideas for in depth thought that you can use in your own imagination. A 
game like Deus Ex is riddled with philisophical ideas, fantacised future 
advancements in technology, and ideas of what roles government and 
corporations can hold in world so full of conspiracy and chaos as the game. 
It can really get someone to think and explore ideas in there own 
imagination.
comments.author: ByTor1212

comments.text:
When was the last time you really looked at something real? Like a blade of 
grass. I mean really looked.
comments.author: skunkhammer

comments.text:
+ByTor1212 Again, video games are seriously limited versus what a vivid 
unrestrained imagination can come up with. Versus what the game gives you 
and what confines you have to stay in the game universe. That's the 
difference. It's nice that you weren't much hampered though.
comments.author: channelvision98

comments.text:
I guess it is a bit of a personal thing because what I meant is that games 
like I had mentioned fueled my own thinking and influenced me to imagine 
new worlds and stories of my own. I do believe i didn't quite focus on that 
bit though.
comments.author: ByTor1212

comments.text:
yeah but video games give it's own fantasy. Imagination is not limited like 
that. That's the difference I think he was trying to say that being outside 
can fuel a child's imagination, that never ending road of ideas, thoughts 
and fantasies. Instead of just a game that gives you it's own bit of 
fantasy that you follow along, and another game will give you another.
comments.author: channelvision98

comments.text:
I believe he is saying.. Nature in reality, when observed in person is 
 better than watching it on a TV screen. As a naturalist I must agree! Go 
outside and leave the video games and artificial world behind! ﻿

comments.author: Garlick Zulander

comments.text: Tada!
comments.author: Griffin the griffin

comments.text: It's refreshing to see that someone on Youtube actually gets irony! :-)
comments.author: John Smith

comments.text:
+Garlick Zulander Huh? Oh, no, I'm not talking about me. I got shit lucky 
and have a job I love. I'm talking about my sister. And my mom. And my dad. 
And my other sister. I'm pointing out that this is how society trains their 
people. I never said it was right, or that we shouldn't fight it, just 
that's how it currently is. Same reason we spend the first year of our 
lives learning to walk and talk, and the next ten being told to sit down 
and shut up.
comments.author: Griffin the griffin

comments.text:
what a sad thing to witness a thinking human being give their life over to 
pointless future and predictable end. You didn't even fight.
comments.author: Garlick Zulander

comments.text:
It's also a fair selling point that unimaginative people will not only 
spend more to keep themselves entertained, but will be more productive in 
daily life. While childhood is all about 'following your dreams' and 
'thinking big', the harsh reality is that when you reach adulthood, you 
will ALMOST certainly spend the rest of your working days doing the same 
things. Likely not even interesting things. Boring things, mindless, 
monotonous, dull things. Imagination causes distraction. Ever sit inside 
doing math homework when the sun outside is shining, you can just picture 
yourself basking in it's rays, going for a run, throwing a ball, sitting 
under a tree? Well, that distraction is causing you not to be as focused on 
your boring mathematics.
comments.author: Griffin the griffin

comments.text:
The title is MISLEADING and WRONG. Correct title would be; Authors book is

100% correct. The news employees were NOT PUNKED. They were however 
unprepared for a realist. That sais alot about their "NEWS", when a news

comments.author: Dan Fall

comments.text:
As with most arguments, political or otherwise, there is an element of 
truth in both sides. Most of what we watch on TV is fictional and not real. 
The fictional appeals to the imagination and the reality shows eliminates 
the need for the imagination. Is "Barney" the purple puppet easier to watch 
than "How it's Made" documentaries? Yes because one appeals to children who 
have great unlimited creative minds but adults have been trained to 
suppress their imaginations by learning to "color inside the lines". 
Perhaps an indepth show on how grass grows might appeal to the younger 
mentality than an episode of "South Park" but you pay the bill, you make 
the choices. It's your mind whether it needs to be entertained or educated, 
it's all there for the taking.﻿

comments.text:
A blade of grass is more wonderess than anything they would see on a screen

comments.author: UtherPendragan

comments.text:
He's right, you shouldn't call him an idiot. I'm not going to call you one.

Infact a blade of grass is more interesting because it is much more 
stimulating to the human mind, leave alone the imagination. Especially for 
developing minds doing anything real is very stimulating, the mind is 
registering more things then you can think of. Then the minds imagination 
gets kicking, thats now where it re imagines what it saw on  TV which looks 
very cool, no it imagines brand new things brand new ideas, this child just 
created a new way of thinking, based on the details he or she specifically 
noticed about that blade of grass. 

Perhaps as a kid you were kept inside and a game system, i didn't.

What i started noticing is many people who were kept inside or had ample 
TV's and game systems, didn't have any ideas, they didn't have any jokes, 
or anything to bring to the table. But they all talked about TV episodes 
that made them laugh, and talked about things they saw other people wear, 
repeating what they said from TV etc.. thats about it, just things they 
saw. Disagree? Tell me why.

comments.text:
Hey YOUNG TURKS, it's really called social satire NOT sarcasm... at any 
rate, great coverage... LOVE the anchor's expressions...  this is usually 
what happens with social satire... the people who are completely ignorant 
of the focal issue NEVER "get it"!  This alone is deeply troubling about 
our society.﻿
comments.author: Sandra Knight

comments.text:
Not to split hairs here... but to split just one teeny tiny hair... sarcasm 
is one technique used to create satire in many situations, a means to an 
end, if you will.  But if you remove sarcasm from the context of the type 
of satire aimed at raising social consciousness then you simply have mean 
spirited humor.  But you are right, in this instance it is both.
comments.author: Sandra Knight

comments.text: It's both.
